review_title: Great job for the right person (in the right country office)
pros:
- Great mix between research and policy angles.
- Broad range of tasks.
- Varying projects, so lots of content variety.
- Opportunities to get involved in research projects and to pick up technical skills (see caveats below).
- Interaction with strong devt academics.
- Lots of space for entrepreneurship, in a policy/research sense.
- A LOT of leave days.

I love it, and I know many others who do as well. They've improved things a good deal across countries, and are also hiring more suitable staff. Some still don't like it, but it's that kind of job - sink or swim!
cons:
- In some countries government engagement is tough and work is accordingly slow.
- Some country directors are not as supportive as others in CEs working on substantial stuff (we're lucky).
- Admin can be annoying (but I really think it's quite manageable, you get paid for it after all and it takes up a fraction of my time).
- Tough going when you don't have work experience, can manage your own time (there's practically no management oversight) and understand LIC policymakers.
- No career progression options, so it's a job for a limited time.
- Contracts are uneven between London-based and field-based staff.
- Few benefits compared with donor jobs.

review_title: Relaxed working culture for some, poor leadership and lack of vision
pros: - Lots of holiday - Overall relaxed working environment (for some) - Work flexibility - Enables entrepreneurial approach to work
cons: - Entrepreneurial approach to work comes as cost of overall clear leadership and vision. - Siloed approach to working, despite relatively small organisation, driven by poor internal communications and working culture. - Top-heavy organisation with limited appropriate experience at top-level management. - Lack of equity across organisation - strong preference for those in 'economist' roles (evidenced by pay disparity and (lack of) recognition). - Overwork members of the organisation without due care for well-being, or appropriate reward. - Poor pay compared to similar roles across third sector job market. - Excessively focused on economic growth without due consideration for environmental impacts and economic distribution. - Resistant to progress new ideas and challenge status quo, in part due to being excessively beholden to country-level leadership. - Little understanding of long-term impact of work, beyond surface level contribution to policy discussions.

pros: Great people, solid focus, and moving toward giving CT more capacity
cons: As with many large orgs, there is a lot of red tape. Also, academic impact potential sometimes triumphs when it shouldn’t
A lot of budget cuts and pressure.

review_title: A great group of people to work with
pros: My colleagues were the best part about this job and the organisation. Everyone - including executive management - was approachable and friendly. I've made some great friends over the 3 years I've worked here.
cons: The biggest con was lack of upward mobility. As well, internal operations was quite chaotic. Although people were great to work with on an individual level, due to the lack of proper managerial oversight and expertise, teams don't often work well with each other. Quite a lot of communication issues and procedural loopholes down which things can get lost.
